Entry.1: Received word from A.M.C. to report when ready
Entry.3:
Passed Dr. Henry

Good bye to children
Entry.4:
Good bye to children

Left for Brisbane
Entry.8:
Started work in Orderly Tent

Left for Home Leave
Entry.9:
Arrived in Grafton on Home Leave.

Little steam children up at wharf one platform to see last of me.

Saw Ed. of examiner with Rita & went home to tea with her.

Chat with Major Blumer whose son turned out to be wounded in thumb.

Rita played Chopin’s as an only piece & on that account I shall always remember it.

Time too short for such a long parting ahead Good bye to Rita for how long?
Entry.10:
Met Fothergill on way to catch train & delighted to find he would be a companion to Brisbane for he goes to enlist.

Would give anything to go to Rita again but it cannot be.

Rev. Ware up at station & two acquaintances to say farewell.

Once again leave Grafton Station but on more serious business than ever before.

Rather inclined to be bluish although the stark fact of parting from Rita is deadening as a numbing of feeling stayed .
Entry.11:
Reached Brisbane & had tea at with Fothergill & Johnson whom we picked up at Murwillumbah. 

Met De Lacey & Saunders & had a glass of port wine with them. 

De Lacey informed me that promotions are out. Thinks I am good for a corporal & raises my spirits, only for a time however.

Arrived at camp I find Clarke will probable be last Corporal & I have been passed over

Depressed & dreary
Entry.12:
Worked in office during the day with thoughts ever of Rita.

Not much work but a lot of fooling.

Feel discontented, chiefly over not being promoted, but secondly over doubt whether I shall see active service.

Hospital work is however .I must steel myself to disappointment & put a brave face on work, whatever it is. I am lucky to be able to serve my country even in a Hospital.

Cannot get over fact that Sgt Christie passed me over when I thought he had faith in me. A wound to my cursed pride.
Entry.14:
Dinner & tea with Mrs. Harding

Communion 7.30

Evensong 7 p.m.
Entry.20:
P.M.O.

60 recruits to 12 P.M.

Busy morning with records. Got through with them in good time.

Camp flooded with visitors when I returned, so I laid low.

According to present feeling I don’t care becomes of me.

I wonder as down with measles whether Christie will stick me in the office when 40 go. Not much chance. Probable P.M.O.
Entry.22:
P.M.O.

Notification to leave for Sydney on Monday
Entry.23:
No word through yet.

Cannot be going to leave
Entry.24:
Left by 
Ba
 Sydney mail at 8.15

Not much fuss & little cheering

Am in charge of the 5 A.M.C. MEN
Entry.25:
Arrived Sydney 11.15 Marched A.M.C. & A.S.C. men up to Barracks. Left for Liverpool at 6.25.

Good reception. S.M. gave us a good feed & fixed us up.
Entry.26:
Vaccinated this morning.

Granted home leave for four days.

No pay & no pennies so not much chance of getting to Grafton.

Wired return for 30/- & walked around with Francis.

He met his friends so I was left.

Saw Curry, Kenney, Miss Jepson & Mrs. Bruce

Went to Soldiers Club in evening & wrote a lot of letters.

No word from Rita yet.
Entry.27:
Received money from Rita.

Visited University in morning & interested in medical , especially the dissecting room.

Stayed with Sergeant (old Indian soldier) during afternoon slept at Naval House
Entry.28:
Visited casualty ward of Prince A. Hospital during morning.

Fingers torn off, sprained wrist 4 other minor affairs. Judging by the nurses attitude there I should soon get sick of Hospital work & I now find I am going in the field.
Entry.29: Spent the day in dodging around town
Entry.30:
Back at camp. 

Am to leave on Wednesday
Entry.31:
Left camp in afternoon & went to Victoria Barracks.

Still no pay & 30/- running very short.

Managed somehow & slept in Guard Room.

A gentleman arrived & tried to pass the sentry. Said he wanted to enlist but the time of night (11 p.m.) was suspicious. Scant courtesy from guards and rightly. Took things high handedly at first & and spoke of having seen officer, who told him to call

Put in cell for the night
Entry.32:
Day of embarkation.

Took men down to boat at 8 A.M.

All arrangements in good order.

Splendid system of fixing men up

Huge crowd assembled on wharf & great excitement as the boat slowly moved away.

I sat on forward bridge & watched vain endeavours of friends to hear what each of other said till afternoon & then left for Melbourne 2 p.m.
Entry.34:
Arrived in Melbourne at 1.30 & berthed at Port Melbourne 2.30.

Mails revealed nothing for me. No leave granted. Men annoyed at first. Talk of breaking leave & at that Capt Hordern attempted to procure it from Commandant but got no reply. Men broke out in a body at 4 p.m. but repulsed by guard.

Fresh guard brought up & fixed bayonets ready.

Another attempt at dark ending in bloodshed

Several men injured in the charge made by
Entry.35:
the men along the wharf officers powerless to quieten men. Mutiny the order of the day.

Two casualties brought to me for first aid.

Gillam pierced in lung & butted in stomach.

Somerville fell in water but rescued. 

Saturday

Men refused to fall in

, minister for defence arrived & gave a speech to men.

I went to Base Hosp. with sick men & on return after sending wires to Rita & Grafton
Entry.36:
found men lined up on wharf & none allowed on board.

Ring leaders picked out & returned. Men who did not want to go on ship expected to leave ranks one man left ranks.

Sunday

After pulling into mid stream left at midnight Saturday.

Total casualties:-

3 men severe bayonet wounds. 2 men cut eyes and few minor injuries.

All quiet now to most men left & of authorities 

 offenders discharging offenders
Entry.37:
Two doctors in place of one left at Melbourne one a Lt. Col. the other a Captain who is now very sea sick.

Found that Capt. put a good word in for me & now I am in full charge of Hospital with rank (temporarily) of Corporal. Possible it will be confirmed later. I hope so anyhow. I am much better off than I should have been with Hospital Unit for I am getting splendid experience.

I have men in hospital
Entry.38:
Two more admitted to hospital & discharge of bayonet wounded men.

Trouble with Flint after I have reported him . Apparently some of the men for nice holiday & get annoyed when expected to do a little work

What a terrible surprise is in store for them in the field and for me too I expect.

Often wonder whether I shall ever do this voyage on the return
Entry.39:
Fairly 
busy
 day.

More trouble with Hunter & Flint.

Hunter is a 
dammed
 lazy scamp.

Still on good terms with Colonel & hope it keeps up for he can do me some good.

Patients doing very well & if they get no worse I am in for a good time.

Have no time to write letters yet however must shake it up now, for we may call at Fremantle & Rita must have a line from me.

August1915
Entry.40:
Sick parade started at 6.45 AM for a change one or two minor accidents to deal with during the day chiefly a cut on the head from falling Fire alarm in the afternoon, went well 

Hunter refused to touch V.D. patients & put in his place by the doctor.

Have only written one & that letter to Rita, so far,
Entry.41:
Filled in later

During this time I have neglected the diary on account of the very sparse amount of spare time at my disposal

Since leaving Melbourne we had a very rough time in the Bight.

There were times when it was distinctly risky to go about the deck, & at one of these two of the crew were washed about on the fore deck, one had a fractured collar bone & the
Entry.43:
other a compound fracture of the humerus 

The setting of these limbs was very good experience for of course I was the doctor’s right hand man.

As far as the A.M.C. things have gradually improved Flint, after his 4 days detention which I was forced to get him has turned out a splendid worker, but .

Marshall & Hunter have been the
Entry.44:
roughest problems & have required the greatest tack. Hunter is so obviously lazy that I had to use very plain language but of cause he attempted abuse.

That however on the was drained out of him, & he has very little to say.

He appears to be coming round now, but I am with him.

Marshall has exhibited bad faith too (so have I too, I expect) but here again plain language in the end wins.
Entry.45:
I must school myself to look steadfastly at all good points & let others background if possible.

Nothing exciting happened on board although but we did hurt by a long way because all the bad characters at Melbourne. 

Some are still on board, as was shown when a party under the influence of liquor obtained from the crew, attempted to raid the saloon bar.

They abused the officers too & for their trouble will probably
Entry.47:
be sent back to Australia from Egypt.

Boxing competitions & sports have been held intermittently, & one can see clearly that every man jack on board, bad or good will give a good account of himself when pushed to it.
Entry.48:
Very busy day today as usual.

Finished stocktaking above & below & have handed completed lists to Lt. Col. who was pleased with them.

No rest for 16 hours.

Had a few minutes off in the evening & attend the final of the box up.

News received of victory in the Baltic Sea; 6 German cruisers sunk by Russians & one dreadnought by British submarine.

It is wonderful & what a difference this news has made in me for I have lost the tired & weary feeling completely
Entry.49:
Stocktaking continued & finished upstairs.

Getting near to Suez now.

The intense heat which has oppressed us for the last day & now has disappeared at the bidding of a cool breeze.

Everybody getting ready to disembark.
Entry.50:
Arrived opposite Suez at about 6 a.m. & over until 11 oclock when we moved into the wharf.

Terribly busy having all medical stores packed ready for disembarkation.

Got kits together & moved our men off into a special carriage reserved for A.M.C.

Train left for Cairo at 2.20 & arrived at 8 or 9. Very interesting country at parts. Goats & camels tended by picturesque Arabs in oases’

Date palms & various plants under cultivation sand for the rest.

Arrived 1st Hosp. at 10 supper & tent.
Entry.51:
Put on job at outpatients dept. as L. Corp: off every afternoon.

Meals at N.C.O.’s mess which is very nice.

Piloted down the Wassa district by an infantry man & vastly surprised at what I saw.

Rather a disappointed afternoon.

Likely to leave for front any day.

Rather depressed at not receiving letters at all, especially from Rita.

Heleopolis is a new clean suburb of Cairo. Only built a few years where once was a desert.
Entry.52:
Work in morning & part of afternoon.

Down in Wassa again with Kennett in evening. Infinitely more impressive at night time.

Glad of a day or twos easy time.

The climate is not exceptionally hot but enough so.

Not troubled by insects except a few flies which are very persistent.

 Not troubled by glare yet & hope not to be.

Natives are extremely interesting.

Some young Egyptian boys are very well looking youngsters.

Cont.
Entry.53:
They are very intelligent picking up scraps of English very quickly; especially swear words which they give with great gusto

Money is the object of all natives while soldiers are here. I expect they make a great deal of it.

Prices are about the same as at home, but I suspect they should be cheaper.

It is hard to know what to pay for things, for one can be sure 

that natives double the price at least.

Safe to give half of what asked I should think.

Met Moh Fiad Helmu of the University at a café & he
Entry.54:
praises the education system here. He advised me to get a billet teaching English after the war is over.

It is worth thinking over at any rate for the wages are good.

The educated class here is in great evidence.

In the native quarters one sees squalor in its worst form.

Houses built of yellow mud looking stuff, crumbling to pieces from each other across a street of a few feet wide.

Filthy with black piccaninies play about the middle of the alley way & dirty natives in multi coloured dress lounge about or go about their occupations.
Entry.55:
This is the first quiet Sunday for some time. A few patients to attend to in morning & just finished (11 a.m.). Wonder what to do now.

Did not have long to wait. At 11.30 a train of wounded arrived; dinner late & another train afterwards, then tea & still another train. Carrying stretchers all the time up stairs & along corridors until my arms felt pulled out & my hands refused to grip.

Fairly done up in the evening but took a stroll & met Mat who was with me on the Suffolk, also man from front. His information was not what could be described as pleasing.
Entry.56:
Plenty of patients in the morning & 3 operations which delayed matters somewhat.

Off at dinner time & slept during afternoon.

Short walk in evening & bed early.- feeling very tired – fault of climate. This seems to be a rather a muggy month for even after a shower in morning I feel upside down.

False alarm in evening that we were going on Wed. Wrote a long letter to Rita & a note to Professor .

More yarns about the front. The general opinion is that it is a perfect hell & a good place to keep away from.
Entry.57:
Not so many patients this morning. Still no letters. Have received one from since leaving Brisbane.

posted of none for weeks.

Note: Hunter lazy on board & here (sick to death of ward duty)

 ( worked got good

 Jarman ( cheerfully jobs & like them

 Francis worked contented

Poor Hunter is continually dodging his work to speak to me. He simply hates his job. Had no initiation on board.

Heard that we may expect to leave for front in a very short time now. Sooner the better.

Relieved Hunter for hour & half in evening & couldn’t say I was impressed by the work.
Entry.58:
Received instructions to prepare to leave tomorrow.

Paid in the morning. Complemented by the Captain for good work in . Sorry to loose me.

Had a flare up in the evening with Hunter with whom I am very good friends now.

Rather a pity I should .

Met Colonel on return & he gave me good wishes & wants me to write how many hundreds of letters
Entry.59:
Good bye to the doctors & and such nurses as I know & away by car to Cairo station catching the midday train for Alexandria. The line runs through the very fertile land in the basin of the Nile delta.

Corn & other crops as far as the eye can see.

Arrived at Alexandria & drafted to Mustapha barracks. Leave in Alex. for evening.

Went in with Kennet & Hunter
Entry.60:
Nothing to do all day but early parade. The camp on the beach is simply lovely & a bath handy. Any amount of Tommies about – Dublin Fusiliers, & various.

Met a Dulwich College old boy who remembered Clifford Hill but not my old friend Leslie Hills of Sr. Olams.

The of the bay is simply lovely.
Entry.61:
Got pay from paymaster in town & visited dentist at Raz – el his hospital to get that offending molar out.

It was rather sore but it has caused me a lot of trouble.

Any amount of French people in town.

French & Italian soldiers 

Cafes after French style, & Cafes Chantant or music halls open all days for payment of stiff prices for drinks.
Entry.62:
Church parade at 9 oclock in Garrison church, which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Am now a permanent lance corporal so that will be something to go to Gallipoli with.

Warned to proceed with the next batch which leaves tomorrow or Tuesday.
Entry.63:
No sign of leaving so spent another day good in Alexandria.

Have sent several letters to Rita & innumerable postcards embracing nearly everybody.

Discovered the Soldiers Rest which fills in gap for there I can rest & read & write while Hunter goes on .

Heard some splendid music there.
Entry.64:
Definitely leaving tomorrow. Another good day in town.

I shall get quite lazy and unfit for work soon.

A wandered in town in evening.

Australian in a fainting fit, put him in a quiet spot found he was suffering from shock event as news of his brothers death on Gallipoli.

Quite broken up about it.

see next page for Wednesday
Entry.65:
Wednesday 15

Reveille at 5.30 a.m.

Lifeboat drill at 10 clock

Took full squad at physical drill at 1 oclock – other wise nothing doing. Wrote to Lily & Rita and few notes in notebook. Had a chat with interpreters & fellow from flying corps who gave interesting account of death of officer by burning (aeroplane). It is particularly noticeable how much more friendly the feeling amongst the men on board this ship is than on the trip from Australia. We are very near to the of anchor now.

September 1915

Saturday 18

Thursday 16

Spent a rough night on deck in the rain but overcame the difficulty by wrapping myself in a waterproof.

The nights are getting much colder now, & the days cooler.

Usual parades & drill with the addition of allotments of places & duties by lifeboat & a lot climbing around discovering falls & man ropes.

If a torpedo hit us I am willing to wager that only half the boats would get away, for the difficulties of a list would require far more organisation than we have.
Entry.66:
Friday 17
 

Paraded at 7.30 & off at 

Embarked about dinner time and after being well settled down, pulled out mid stream about sundown.

Mostly Tommies on board a good many inexperienced officers.

Felt rather lonely at night & went to sleep on deck while listening to an impromptu concert by some sailors. Still in midstream when went to sleep.
Entry.68:
Up early & found we were still in mid stream anchored near a French warship.

Paraded & took a squad at physical drill.

Nothing else to do today. Still anchored when we came up from dinner.

Hospital ship just in.

Rumours of torpedoes outside.

Left at sundown just as a transport from England absolutely crammed with soldiers arrived.

Out of sight of land at dark.
Entry.69:
Holy communion at 6 a.m. Did a little more work today.

On lifebuoy watch for 24 hours in charge of three men taking 8 pm to 11 pm watch.

Arrived at Lemnos at 4 a.m. slowly steaming up Mudros harbour between 2 rows of torpedo nets & mines.

Destroyer ? vanguard all day, both her & our own boat zig zagged like fun for danger of torpedoes very great indeed.

Mudros harbour full of cruisers, hospital ships & transports.
Entry.70:
Still anchored out in the harbour.

Medical inspection at 10.30 at which I assisted the doctor.

Royal George crammed with troops arrived in the afternoon.

After tea received instructions to proceed to Anzac at 12 tomorrow.

Everyone excited to a mild degree & plenty of chaff going the rounds.

Had a good yarn on a variety of topics with a man well read & interesting. Comes from near Birkenhead.

Wish I had met him earlier.
Entry.71:
Spent the morning in fiddling about which means doing nothing. Apparently the authorities are going to depart their usual custom & get us off as arranged.

Oh dear no. No such thing. "A.M.C. go to Anzac 
eventually"
 tomorrow possibly but no earlier. Did my washing tonight after putting it off & off.

Had some fun with the boys in the afternoon the present moment my Birkenhead friend is waiting for a yarn.
Entry.72:
Supposed to land at 11 a.m. Mudros which is on the eastern side of the island but got under way at about 4 oclock. 

Had to search out the Aust. A.M.C. headquarters & then reported the arrival of 16 men to the .

Temporarily attached the 1st Austral. Hosp. for duty.

Miller Robson & Morris got about 50 letters each which made me jealous.

Had a walk through the village (a few rough huts) in the evening.
Entry.73:
Put on fatigue work fixing up tents.

It is very healthy here but the rough wind makes the sand a nuisance at times.

A collection of Turkish prisoners is here, and plenty of Ghurkhas French & Tommies.

The island evidently belongs to Greece for there are a few Greeks in the mud hovels of the village.

The hospital seems to be arranged on good lines for all the marquees are in orderly lines & paths are edged with white stones.
Entry.74:
Still on fatigue work but did not overwork.

There are not a great amount of invalids here for the hospital is expected to move to Anzac any day.

Got notice to parade at 6 p.m.

Paraded & got kits ready to move away. Taken in ambulance to camp commandants camp over on an island which is reached by a causeway of stones.

Miserable 

 camp; had to sleep out to avoid lice.
Entry.75:
Left by ferry for Inter Base & after landing had to walk 3 miles carrying full kits to base camp.

This camp is pretty miserable but is situated on a hill with a good view. There are 3 villages in sight & they look picturesque in the distance. The sunset over the hills reflected on these collections of stone house made a very nice view.

Food very poor – bread hard biscuits, rice & bully beef stew.

Informed that we move on to Anzac in the morning at 7 oclock.
Entry.76:
Rose at 5 oclock & went to Holy Communion at 6.

There were only 3 there but I felt the benefit of it. 

Had a curious dream last night. Mr. & Mrs. Hart, Bobby & Rita were washed out to sea & I saved Rita & Bobby but could not reach Mr. & Mrs. Hart. 

Rita must have been thinking of me a lot today for I feel she is close to me.

Left camp at 7.30 carrying pack on back, blankets & waterproof & also black kit bag, marched 4 miles to jetty, only to find we were here a day too soon so had to march back again ( left kit behind and went to village in evening 

 

+ Gallipoli
Entry.77:
Once more we rose at 5 a.m. & got off at 7.30. Easier walking minus black kit bag & blankets, which I found intact on arriving at jetty – found some hot water on a boat & made some coffee. Sailed by the "Partridge" ( an auxiliary gunboat originally a was channel steamer) for Anzac at 5p.m.

At 7 p.m. saw flash of big guns in the distance as we hugged the shore.

At 8 p.m. drew up opposite Anzac Cove ( where the first landing took place). Saw bombardment by a destroyer & heard firing in distance landed & bombed by German aeroplane – no casualties. 

LANDED AT MIDNIGHT MONDAY AND TOUCHED SOIL IN FIRST MOMENTS OF BIRTHDAY
Entry.78:
Rose at daybreak & went with Hunter to Hqtr 3rd Field Ambulance situated on the beach & then to camp in a large gully running up from the beach a mile inland. Reported & received ½ doz letters including proofs of photos & 2 letters from Rita which were welcome. Were welcomed with a few shrapnel shells one of which burst near enough to cause us to duck..

Safely ensconced in a good dugout.

The 3rd Field Hospital & stores are behind a hill in view of the sea & of the corner swept by "Beachy Bill"
Entry.79:
Put on stretcher & went to ‘Shell Green" for 24 hours duty.

A clear flat crest to hill is "Shell Green" no longer green but brown.

Very dangerous when artillery active because several guns round it which the Turks fire at.

Several .75 shells burst around the green and one burst at a dug out 10 yards away, wounding 2 men, one of whom died soon after we got him in.

Total for the day till dark 6 men including a brigadier wounded in neck.

Heard a lot about Simpson from boys. (in trenches) 

September 1915
Entry.80:
On camp fatigue.

All that required to be done was carrying water & rations. Getting used to being under fire although when a shrapnel comes rather close it gives one a bit of a fright.

 Several aeroplanes mostly our own overhead during the day observing for the warships firing over to the Turkish lines.

It is interesting to see the shells fired by the Turks bursting near the shore (sometimes).

They are not very successful at that kind of firing.
Entry.81:
Detailed for fatigue work in Artillery lane.

An old dressing station to be turned in to a new one. Plenty of digging.

This station is further north & higher up than Shell Green which is visible away to the left.

I think this place is more dangerous than "Shell Green" for shells were bursting around for a good part of the day.

On the way home stopped at a gun on the way looking south & therefore overlooking "Gaba Tepe". Looked through glasses & saw trenches on the olive groves flat.
Entry.82:
Heavy duty in Artillery Lane which was no different to the fatigue of yesterday with difference of staying all night.

No cases to .

Getting quite used to Beachy Bill now.

Last night there was a little doing on the left for at sunset there was a heavy artillery with mostly the firing being from our own guns.

After dark there was heavy artillery fire which of course sounds like a rifle range only heavier with the addition of the sharp repeated cracks of the machine guns.
Entry.83:
Light duty today for a change.

Got some firewood from the hill during day & did little else except write some letters & read "Vanity Fair".

Heard that the firing on the left a couple of days ago resulted in 1000 yds gain.

Three hospital ships in the bay & several visits from our aeroplanes overhead.
Entry.84:
"Shell Green" dressing station for 24 hrs duty. Received letter from Prof. Helmy of Cairo & letter from J.W.Holt !

6 casualties up till sunset, all resulting from a violent artillery attack in the morning.

The shells burst all round the dressing station & there was a constant rain of pellets & lumps of all round, right up to the very the door of the shed.

Demonstration at 8.15 p.m. with vast amount of artillery & lot of rifle fire but no casualties (only a sham).
Entry.85:
Fatigue duties during the day.

Work hard while it lasts but not regular at present & but not regularly at present from what information I have gained it seems that when a charge is on from Shell Green the track goes down a very steep gully, up a mound in the gully, down & up to the opposite ridge. Thence it runs through a sap in front of a gun (4.7) & down an incline to the 2nd L.H. I. & where we leave the patients.

Total distance nearly a mile.

Own Art.have the track
Entry.86:
goes round the hill parallel with the trenches then leaving the road turns to the left towards the sea, & sharply down. Thence it is downhill all the way to a road which leads to the sap before mentioned.

Total distance about 1 mile.

A bearer has to keep going on either of these tracks under heavy shrapnel fire for 24 hours or more when a charge is on, dark or light.

Thus he does his bit.
Entry.87:
Artillery Road dressing station. No cases.

Rather surprising that for at 8.30 p.m. a sham stunt started.

First came a few stray rifle shots, then the rattle of bags of cans being shot over the edge of 
the
 our trenches, whence they rolled towards the Turks trenches. This occasioned a terrific fire from them & at once a star shell made its appearance.

In the midst of this hurricane of rifle fire came a rapid carronade from a monitor & destroyer directed at some important target.

Stunt lasted an hour.
Entry.88:
Fatigue duties in camp.

Dissolved partnership with Hunter & got a dug out for myself, to be independent & save a lot of trouble.

A fair amount of free gift supplies ( chocolate etc.) arrived & were brought up with rations in afternoon.

First rain since landing came after dark with a brisk wind 
right
 causing alterations to be necessary for the dugout.
Entry.89:
Artillery lane again.

Nothing exciting during the day. Just a few artillery shots.
Entry.90:
Fatigues in camp.

Feeling a little indisposed.
Entry.91:
Shell Green dressing station. 2 cases. Still feeling rather poor.

Hunter on sick list & Lands fainted when standing with a case during the night.
Entry.92:
a.m. fatigue in camp feeling very much better.

Greatly
 pleased to receive a letter from Rita and also a splendid pocket Bible – a treasure. 

Feeling good now.

Also letter from Kennedy, late of Hereford.
Entry.93:
At Artillery Rd. dress stat

Aeroplanes have been circling over our flank very low down

 for some days now. I have hoped that something may be expected on this flank before very long. Possibly Ghurkhas may try to straighten the line out at Lone Pine.

Heard that a certain General said we should be finished here by Christmas. Very cold to-day – cold continues all through day instead of only night as heretofore. 

General Walker hit in arm by ricochet bullet.
Entry.94:
Wood fatigue in camp away ill.

Received letter & birthday card from Rita letter from Woodlawn.

Hear we are going to England – just the usual rumour I suspect. 

Wrote long letter to Rita.

Feel in very good health.

Had a good look around trenches yesterday & saw Gun ridge which they say would finish the business if taken. Seems an improbable task.

The line at Popes Hill on left is very near the Narrows & surely we cannot keep getting across in time.
Entry.95:
Artillery Lane Station.

Very good day indeed but during the afternoon news received that a general attack will be made at 4 oclock in the morning mainly on the left. They say that a disparate attempt will be made to get right through this time.

Stormy times ahead.

I sincerely hope & pray that it will be successful if that is what is intended.
Entry.99:
a.m. fatigues.

Artillery duel in morning.

Had first narrow escape. Sitting in dug out after breakfast when a thud on loose earth startled me, sending a shower of earth down.

Turned out to be a shell cap.

A foot to the right & I should not be writing this.
Entry.100:
Artillery Lane.

No patients in morning.

Heard that Sir Ian H. has been recalled & Gen Munro sent in his place. 

Fellows very pessimistic so tried a little optimism on them, chiefly of the "Watch Russia" description.
Entry.101:
Appointed batman to Major Quick & like a fool, accepted it. Found on arrival at the site of my new duties that I have to help two other batmen attend to four, - taking the meals – waiting 
daily
 every other day with one of them while the other does all cooking.

Absolutely rotten ! ! 

Narrow escape; shrap pellet alighted two inches from my toe as I was standing in front of dug out.
Entry.102:
My turn to wait at table & managed to get through with nothing worse than spilling rice all over the table.

Very easy job, for tomorrow I simply clean a dug – out & get some water & then "Finish".

Started raining in afternoon.

Very miserable day. Feeling rather sick.
Entry.103:
Decided to give the job best so applied to Staff Serg. to allow me to get back to stretcher work & let take my place.

They both thought me mad for batman’s job is notoriously "good" but I fail to see it absolutely.

Arrived back at camp before dinner & began to feel worse.

Capt. Conrick said he was glad to get me back & I shuddered to think of going on sick parade so turned into dug out & took some medicine.

Temperature 102°.
Entry.104:
Slightly better this morning so went up the gully on duty.

Work all day.

but next morning better
Entry.105:
Feeling better on rising but during the day got worse.

Scrambled through fatigue somehow, & on someones advice took aspirin which fixed me up helped by a nip of whiskey from Roberts who with Kause ( 7th Reinforcements) .

Another narrow escape. A shell landed a foot from head while I was in Robert’s dugout
Entry.107:
Wood fatigue.

Received two letters from , two from Dad & two from Rita.
Entry.108:
Shell Green dressing stat everything is still very quiet.

A couple of cases during day.

Slight bombardment.
Entry.109:
Tent pitching & odd jobs.

Turkish fire very heavy in morning

Several shells fell in over our camp & a great number just over the hill.

Shrapnel falling all over the place.

Roberts hit by spent pellet, but only bruised.

Jack & two others sent away on the sick list.

The number of sick sent away is alarming.

Heard that Allied troops are landing at Salonica to help Servians.
Entry.110:
A.M.’s fatigue

Arrival of 30 odd reinforcements from A.G.H. & belonging to other ambulances especially the 7th. Among them was the chap I passed at Brisbane prominent in the Daily Mail picture. Coincidence No.1 for he first went in to Infantry.

Coin. No.2. Met Jack Buckle of days, down in Army Service Corps.
Entry.111:
Artillery Rd.

Went into the trenches today & had a good yarn with the fellows

All seem to think 
of
 a change is a likely thing in the near future.

The 

 trenches are being strengthened & prepared for such a contingency.

Parts of the units which that to Mudros for a rest have returned & the rumour of our immanent departure is once more on the rounds. The position is that the 3rd Brig. who landed first are still at it.
Entry.112:
Busy day helping Bonner with an annex to the Hospital. Sawed wood in the morning until I thought that my arms would fall off.

Lately the artillery seem to have sprung to life again for a day never passes without a few shells from the "Olive Grove" – five & six at a time instead of singly as formerly. Turks have evidently established fresh batteries there. The firing is not one sided .
Entry.113:
Day off.

First time for a considerable time.

Went down to the beach in the afternoon to get beef or condensed milk, but got neither. Very narrow escape from shrapnel pellets outside officers mess. Beach was absolutely rained on by shrapnel. Had Roberts & Kause to tea, but can hardly call it a success for the porridge & cocoa were not ready until nearly all were tired of waiting for them.
Entry.114:
Letter from Rita/photo have arrived.

Shell Green dressing Stat

First case in morning: a man shot with high explosive through shin.

Returning thru gully at foot of Green when a 75 burst over Artillery Rd. sending pellets all round me. Calls from all parts for stretcher bearers & doctors. Major Butler famous for charging with Infantry ( vide Australian Press at time of landing) was working near me & he was unhurt while two men near him were wounded. One of our men at Artillery Rd. wounded. Pellets struck ground a foot from me later – luck holds.
Entry.115:
Off duty

Did nothing in particular except fiddle round dugout & write to Rita in the evening.

Received free ( & 2 of apple) in afternoon.

Very welcome.
Entry.116:
Light horse captured a trench from the Turks & made another by sapping cut.

Turks tried to bomb them out but were unsuccessful.

New squad from / station, carrying along the beach.
Entry.117:
Beach dressing station.

Working all day & part of the night, although I felt very ill.

Move on the left side in progress.

Beachy landed shell (from howitzer) clean down the hold of barge at pier opposite one dressing station.

One killed & two wounded one simply cut to pieces.
Entry.118:
Off duty.

Went on sick parade. Debility the doctor said but suspect something else.
Entry.120:
Off duty.

Sick parade again. Doctor discovered it is jaundice.

Felling rotten, & should be sorry when the attack wears off.

Wrote to Dad &

 Rita.

Sent off service cards & Christmas cards to Australia.

November,1915
Entry.121:
Artillery Rd. station.

Bomb came over & burst on top of 6th Field Amb. dressing station up the road towards Lone Pine & killed & injured a half dozen.

One case of sickness for us in the night.

Mail in but so far no letters for me.

This jaundice has a most depressing effect on one.

Wonder how I’ll ever stick it till the war finishes, but 
that
 feeling will pass with the sickness.
Entry.122:
Off duty & put on light by doctor.

Feeling better in evening.
Entry.123: Off duty all day but due for Chatham’s Post at night.
Entry.125:
In hospital.

Howitzer fell into Hospital cookhouse & wounded & Taylor (3rd time) & Sergt Hayes.

 badly burned all over & not expected to recover.
Entry.131:
Discharged from hospital.

Feeling good.

Cheese & treacle are beginning to be issued now.

Have developed an enormous appetite. 

Carrying becoming rather strenuous work. 

 J. Boyd Smith both of ours killed by a high explosive Jack Johnson round on the left to us.

Shells are getting thicker every day now.

Horrible howitzers are falling all round & in the camp.
Entry.133:
Put on sanitation piquet by Capt Cornick as carrying affects the eye, possibly on account of weakness of body.

Not a good job but very easy.
Entry.134:
Blizzards have begun to set in in a mild form of .

Cold winds from north sweep our side all day & make in the day necessary.
Entry.135:
After a bitterly cold wind last night, woke up to find snow this morning.

Bitterly cold wind blowing all day: simply impossible to keep feet & hands warm.

It is miserable working 
all
 Several water tanks frozen & pipes burst so 
that
 us to quarter rations of water or just enough for a couple of small drinks a day as tea.
Entry.136:
Still cold & snowing but the wind is dropping & so for us for we could get the circulation going.

Walked over to Bridges Rd. – about a mile – for water & got quarter rations last night the Turks bombarded Lone Pine trenches & killed or wounded 250. 

60 were caught in a tunnel & buried alive.

Our camp was shelled by heavy howitzers but no damage was done for most of them
Entry.137:
failed to explode but the 6th Field Amb.suffered badly.

One officer was killed while operating & half a dozen men were killed.

The Turks have certainly got fresh guns & more ammunition than we get no rest all day for these miserable howitzers.

One hears a droning noise in the distance which increase as the shell comes closer, but quite slowly. Suddenly when it is near there is a whiz, it strikes the
Entry.138:
earth & explodes.

A sheet of flame goes up into the air, there is a deafening explosion and earth sandbags & 
all
 huge lumps of shell fly in all directions.

The worst of these shells is that a man stands little chance of getting out alive except with the loss of a limb or a terrible wound.
Entry.139:
No. 1 Stationary Hospital shelled. One high explosive dropped clear into a ward tent & hit six of the staff four died & 2 were wounded one of whom will lose his leg.

It seems inhuman for helpless men to be shelled whose fault it is I cannot say, for there are guns of ours very near – it is at these that the Turks fire I think, but something should be done.

The trouble is that we are so cramped for room.

Saturday, 1915
Entry.140:
Worked at the incinerator in morning & lit it just as the howitzer started firing.

Unfortunately it made a big smoke & up came the artillery major with "Put the b—fire out its obscuring our aiming post & will attract fire". Worked like hell to put it out. In the afternoon it started again while Bourne was getting wood. Got it out. Shells 
burst
 bursting all roads all day.

Had to stick there in the open. Just finished when Beachy Bill burst right overhead & gave me a pellet in the right thigh.
Entry.141:
Never slept a wink all night for the ache of my leg, mostly due to the rotten stretcher.

No hospital ship in so will remain at Clearing Hospital until one comes 

Heard 
that
 no ship nearer than Alexandria.

How heartily I cursed the man responsible for this blunder not on my own account so much as other & worse cases.

There is an amputation opposite me & a loss of sight to the left,
Entry.142:
Morphia last night whilst away on the right is a case where the lower part of the jaw has been blown away.

He has to write on paper for what he wants.

One small hospital ship in but that utilized for walking cases, having no accommodation for beds.

Heavy shelling going on all the time around Hospital.

No. 16 Hospital bombarded & one tent smashed to pieces. About 20 casualties. Poor fellows.
Entry.143:
Still shelling.

Howitzer started again in the afternoon & smashed a dugout near our ward.

I felt pretty " perspirey" laying helpless on my back. 

Hurried orders to send walking cases to the sap, & stand-by stretcher cases.

3 more shells – whistling slowly towards us – the terrible suspense!

Then they burst further away & all was quiet again.

Egyptians mistook bomb for & six brought in Hospital ship.
Entry.144:
Transferred to Hospital Ship early in morning.

As barge drew near ship I saw a nurse on board - first white lady for 3 or 4 months. Seems delightful to get to comfort after the hell over there.

A spell will do a man a world of good.

Taken in cradle on a crane from barge to ship then down a lift & along a corridor to ward.

Put in a cot with clean sheets, washed & put in pyjamas.

Surely the Castle’ is an earthly heaven!
Entry.145:
Arrived at Mudros last night.

Could not see anything of course. Anchored all night & left at 10 this morning for Alexandria.

Food plain but simply delicious after those biscuits & awful bully beef.
Entry.146:
Anglo Indian doctors, R.A.M.C. orderlies & nurses of Queen Alexander’s nursing reserve on board.

Treated splendidly.

Leg quite straightforward & progressing wonderfully.

Wrote field service cards for about 8 people.

Getting fit again onboard with the good food.
Entry.147:
Arrived in Alexandria at wharf during the morning.

Disembarked to hospital train in afternoon where we were accommodated in bunks.

During the ride to Cairo we were served with tea, chocolate & cigarettes by the nurse & red cross lady.

Arrived at back of 1st A.G.H., Derbyshire was the first man aboard. He brought Kennett & Lightbody & in a few minutes I had met a lot of old friends. Woodberry an old room mate is orderly in No.10 ward to which I was sent.
Entry.148:
My first day in 1st A.G.H. as a patient. Food splendid – nurses great – everything glorious.

Sent cable to Rita reassuring her & here the diary must draw to a close for there is nothing exciting to put in.
